title: 103_s143
content: The National Academies of Practice is recognized and granted a Federal charter with specific corporate powers outlined in its bylaws. The corporation's purposes include honoring individuals in various healthcare professions and improving practices through the dissemination of information. The corporation must comply with state laws for service of process, membership eligibility and rights are outlined in the bylaws, the board of directors' composition and responsibilities are defined in the articles of incorporation, and officers are elected according to state laws and the articles of incorporation. SEC. 8. RESTRICTIONS. The corporation is restricted from distributing income or assets to members, officers, or directors. Reasonable compensation and reimbursement for expenses are allowed. Loans to officers, directors, or employees are prohibited. Political activity and attempts to influence legislation are also prohibited. The corporation cannot issue stock or pay dividends. The corporation is prohibited from issuing stock or paying dividends. It cannot claim congressional approval or Federal Government authority for its activities. The corporation is liable for the acts of its officers and agents within their authority. Maintenance and inspection of books and records are required. The corporation must maintain correct and complete books and records of account, including minutes of proceedings involving members, the board of directors, or committees. It must also keep a record of members' names and addresses at its principal office. Members have the right to inspect the books and records for any proper purpose. This section does not override any applicable State law. Additionally, there is a provision for auditing financial transactions. SEC. 11. Audit of financial transactions amended to include National Academies of Practice. SEC. 12. Annual report. The corporation must provide an annual report to Congress on its activities, maintain tax-exempt status, and the right to amend or repeal the Act is reserved to Congress. If the corporation fails to comply with any restrictions or provisions of this Act, the charter granted by this Act shall terminate.
